div1.head: Jim to M. Paul Rockwell, Saturday May 8th ‘15
div1.p: Again the pleasure of hearing from you, and as I’ve just returned from a place de secour and won’t have another call for a few minutes I’m taking the opportunity of getting a line off to you.

I told you didn’t I about the close call one of us had when a shell tore off the top of a car, missing the driver’s head by ten inches. We got another heavy
bombardment yesterday but it didn’t stir up much dust.

Its very eerie working out here at night. One carries no lights; even cigarettes are forbidden for they can be seen from the enemy trucks and might draw fire. One creeps slowly past convoy, after convoy, past sentinels who cry “Halte la” and get cussed out by a reproachful “Ambulance Mon vieux!”, and it is only in the dazzling light of the illuminating shells that hurtle into the sky and sink slowly over the trenches that one can run with any speed.
Its a safe bet that when the Boches are forced from their position near here that they will retaliate by blowing our advance point off the map. It doesn’t seem to bother the cheerful, easy going denizens of the berg. All the stores, save those that have been shattered, are running full blast, and one may purchase most anything; the factories are running; the cafes are crowded, and right now between the roar of heavy artillery I can hear the high pitched drone
of children’s voices reciting the lesson for the day in the little school across the garden from us.
The gardens here are beautiful. I recommend the place highly as a honeymooning point and hope you’ll come up after the big event. Sorry you have to delay the big happening on your account.

We’ve made good up here and as a result the French section has received orders to pull out Monday for another
point, turning all the work over to us. We are being treated beautifully. We have a Marechal des logis; and Salisbury our Chief has been made a sous lieutenant for the war. The grub is O.K. and our sleeping quarters, even at our advance point, are comfortable. We expect to leave our base and live at the advance point all the time. It adds considerably to the speed
of our work. Its naturally reducing the chances of getting out of the fight with a whole skin, but ‘what the hell Bill what the hell’ as our old friend Eugene Field so aptly remarked in that tender set of verses anent the screw fest of the greaser and the border bat.

We have a new form of amusement now which consists of going to the end of a certain street where we are in full view of the German trenches fourteen hundred
yards away and testing out whether we can get them to take a couple of pot shots. I’ll give a brown derby to any Boche that can hit at that distance. Our uniform ought to make them mad enough.

By the way I got a nice letter from Mlle. Guerin who spoke highly of you and another letter from no less a cutie than our little friend Elizabeth Baldwin, to
whom I sent a postal.

We’re just about due for another large fight in a couple of days and I hope to God the Germans get all shot to hell. We’ve got a hundred and fifty of em [sic] at our base now working as a white wings gang.
The spring has come to us now and its very beautiful out here.
